Comments_List: Great overview of immunology! I feel like a stronger foundational understanding of the subject, which will definitely help my PhD work.
Learned the basics of how the immune system works
By taking this class I learned fundamental concepts in immunology, especially the framework that the innate immunity initiates the adaptive immunity.
I learned about the basic concepts of how the immune system is organized and functions in response to infection.
Further refining of my immunology knowledge.

I came away from the course with a much better understanding of the overall organization of the human immune system. More specifically, I gained a much more nuanced understanding of patterns of immune cell trafficking throughout the body.

Solid overview of the innate and adaptive immune system with some lectures focused specific application i.e. vaccines, cancer immunology. 

I feel much more comfortable with understanding basic immune biology after this course.
I learned a lot about immunology
General overview of immunology and an understanding of current thought in the field

Despite being taught by multiple professors, the course was well integrated.
The course was a little slow to start - there were too many "intro" lectures.
I really like how 1) lectures are recorded 2) TA sessions are held regularly 3) written assignments force you to keep up

Strengths:
1) The topics are very wide-ranging but at the same time up-to-date (e.g. recent discoveries in the novel transcription factor Fezf2 that regulate the ectopic expression of tissue-specific antigens).
2) The quality of classes taught by different instructors are consistently high. All instructors were articulate and used chalk board, maximizing the amount of knowledge the student can absorb.
3) The review session was very necessary and helpful. The papers assigned were informative and fun-to-read.

Weaknesses:
1) The quality of the audio recording could be improved.
2) The homework seems a bit extraby doing the homework, I did not learn much. There might be other ways where one can be tested and evaluated.

The strength of this course were the lectures about VDJ recombination, lymphocyte development and MHC/peptide loading. The lectures about germinal centers and tolerance were also very good. 

Overall, I wish the course went into more in depth concepts and the current questions that are still being asked in the field.

I think the course was excellent. My only critique was that some of the material was redundant between lectures, and I think this could be avoided if the professors were informed about the content of previous lectures.
Maybe the flow of material could be improved for the beginning sections. But that's a maybe. For the most parts, the lectures do a good job of presenting material that is used in subsequent lectures.

I think that the recordings need to be better to be actually helpful. If the person typing the notes could sit further away from the video, it would be really helpful. Also, if the people would wear their mics so that we could here, that would also be useful.
Great to have rotating lecturerers
Definitely! Take this course if you are an advanced undergrad or a 1st year grad student interested gaining a foundation in immunology.
This was great, but that might have just been my TA
Yes, I would highly recommend this course to students who are interested in immunology. It is truly amazing to learn from the best.
Yes. The course is a good introduction to students that have not taken immunology before.
Definitely, especially if the student has a great work ethic and is particularly interested in immunology or other related topics in biomedicine such as microbiology.
Absolutely! This is probably the best-taught course I've taken at Yale.
Would definitely want to recommend if you are doing anything bioscience related because of the importance of the immune system
Yes, though probably only if they have a little immunology background, even just a basic understanding of terms.
yes
